ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Students interested in energy policy, this is a must take course

I thought that this was going to be a course on energy laws in the U.S., instead we really just reviewedthe same policy issues that we discuss in other energy classes already in less detail, with less accuracy, and with less structure. The final paper was somewhat conducive to learning because we could dive into an area of policy of our own choosing so I could think about something that I hadn't worked on in other classes, but at the same time it was so open ended and there was so little direction given as to what was expected that it made it very difficult and stressful to figure out what to do. The readings were interesting, especially Graetz and Yergin, but the assignments were too long to really complete each week and they did not really teach us energy laws as much as energy issues over time.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The second two readings were interesting.
The best and useful part of this course is to critically analyze the US energy policy from three different authors - Yergin, Vietor and Graetz. Very interesting and diverse perspectives.
It was helpful to read different perspectives on the role of policy to shape energy markets.
Bringing the authors in to discuss their books.
The excuse to read Dan Yergin's The Quest and Graetz's The End of Energy.

The readings were excellent, the emphasis on discussion was also very valuable. The three books covered different views and opinions on relevant energy topics with a good introduction to a history of energy. As an FES student, the law class provided a very different perspective.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Professor Elliott never had a clear/comprehensive format, so discussions were all over the place and difficult to follow. It would be much more interesting to have a formatted and outlined discussion of U.S. energy policy tied back to the readings and with case studies than the format employed. I would have learned much more had a different approach been used.
The course has met my expectations and i like the way the present approach.
It would help to have a few more up-to-date short readings to connect how historical policymaking has shaped what is going on today.
I really wish Elliot would not have interrupted people during their final presentation, it just threw everyone and everything off.
The professor conducts the class with no structure and rather than guiding the discussion, he often uses the time to rant about his own opinions which are not always grounded in facts.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Students were given an opportunity to work in a team and make presentation on the topic given. Very useful process.
N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Since i am interested in environmental policy including the energy policy, this course was very relevant to me. I wish to apply my experience in drawing up the energy policy in my country.
As someone focused on energy issues, this class provides the historical context for energy policy.
The material was mostly redundant with other energy courses at FES. It would have been unique if it really focused on energy law, but it really just focused on policy issues as do other courses.
Helped to augment the energy curriculum within FES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about U.S. Energy Law, though I do not feel like that was fulfilled by the class.
same as the answer under question 17
To fill in gaps of my knowledge about energy policy.
I wanted a two credit course on energy.
I wanted to learn about Energy Law as they existed and currently exist.
To get an overview and introduction to relevant energy topics both in the past and present.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No.
Yes, the course was upto my expectations and i am very happy that i took this course.
Yes
Yes.
No, the course material was so unstructured that it was very difficult to find the practical law information I was looking for.
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Learning from peers.

Advantage:- learn from diverse perspective each person bring in. I had a great opportunity learning from the students who know so much about theenergy.Disadvantage:- agreeing on a timing convenient to all was a biggest problem.
N/A

The advantage of the work group was that it gave me an opportunity to work with law students. The disadvantage was that the group assignment was something that was added on after the shopping/drop period ended and was extra work that was not on the initial syllabus.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would not recommend this course to other students.
- No one would regret taking this course. It is a course worth taking.
Brainstorm final paper topic early.
Take it if you like 20th century history and want to understand the historical context of why our energy system is so messed up.
I would not recommend this course for FES students who have taken other energy courses at FES. Just read Yergin and Graetz on your own.
